title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.12.24 Part 2 | 30-08-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyanati Mirandhasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chaksharanmeelitam Jena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The session begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: This child will be almost as good as Lord Shri Krishna Following in his footsteps In magnanimity he will become as great as King Rantideva And in religion he will be like Maharaja Yayati
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse to be discussed, focusing on the comparison of the child Parikshit to King Rantideva in terms of magnanimity.

segments.key_quote: Rantideva was a great King Liberal for hospitality and distribution of foodstuff
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the qualities of King Rantideva, highlighting his hospitality, charity, and saintly nature, emphasizing that he was a 'rajarshi'.

segments.key_quote: even lord sri krishna praised his acts of charity and hospitality this is the greatness of rantideva
segments.summary: The speaker continues to describe Rantideva's virtues, including his acts of charity, hospitality, and adherence to religious principles, noting that he never ate flesh.

segments.key_quote: he never endeavored to earn anything but he would enjoy whatever he got by the arrangement of providence
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Rantideva didn't strive for material gain but accepted what came through providence, but he always gave everything to guests, even undergoing suffering.

segments.key_quote: because Ranthi Deva is perceived the presence of the supreme Godhead everywhere and in every living entity he received guests with faith and respect and gave him a share of the food
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of Rantideva breaking his 48-day fast and offering food to a Brahmana guest, demonstrating his unwavering hospitality and spiritual vision.

segments.key_quote: seeing the shudra in relationship with the supreme personality of godhead king rantideva gave him also a share of the food see the magnanimity of rantideva
segments.summary: The story continues with Rantideva offering food to a Shudra guest, highlighting his spiritual vision of seeing everyone in relation to Krishna and demonstrating true equality.

segments.key_quote: rantideva offered the balance of the food to the dogs and the master of the dogs would come as guests the king offered them all respects and obeisances
segments.summary: The speaker describes Rantideva offering food and respect to a guest with dogs, clarifying that this is based on spiritual vision and should not be imitated superficially, emphasizing the importance of cleanliness and proper discrimination.

segments.key_quote: I do not pray to the Supreme Personality of God it for the eight perfections of mystic yoga not for Salvation from repeated birth and death I want to only stay out of the difamento deræ„›
segments.summary: The story culminates with Rantideva offering his last portion of water to a Chandala, expressing his desire to alleviate the suffering of all beings, showcasing his ultimate magnanimity.

segments.key_quote: the demigods like Lord Brahma and Lord Shiva they had disguised themselves and appeared as the brahmana the shudra the master of the dogs and the chandala they disclosed their identity and they said we are very pleased with your generosity with your magnanimity kindly ask us any benediction
segments.summary: The demigods reveal themselves, pleased with Rantideva's generosity, and Rantideva prays for devotion to Lord Vishnu, reinforcing the theme of magnanimity and its connection to spiritual realization; the speaker concludes by reiterating that Parikshit will be as magnanimous as Rantideva.
